date: stated on October 1, 2015 in a Facebook post:
title: :: Verification of the accuracy of the comparison of deaths caused by firearms and deaths caused by terrorism
text: Following the first October shooting at the Umbukwa Community College in Oregon, President Barack Obama commissioned the media to put the number of deaths associated with armed violence in perspective. "Get news organizations to count the number of Americans killed through terrorist attacks in the last decade and the number of Americans killed by gun violence." "We spend more than $1 trillion, we pass countless laws, and we devote full agencies to preventing terrorist attacks on our territory, and rightly so. However, we have Congress that clearly prevents us from even collecting data on how we can reduce the probability of killing guns. How could that be?" The main point of Obama was to highlight the lack of resources and legislative action on armed violence. Some have questioned the usefulness of this comparison - for example, critics have pointed out that cigarettes kill more people than guns. We don't weigh in that debate. Instead, we're just looking at data. Multiple binding outlets (although each came with slightly different numbers). Many readers asked us to check one specific widely shared comparison on Facebook and Twitter. Established by Nowthis, a New York-based news company that produces content specifically for social media. The picture says that 24 Americans have been killed by terror in the last decade, while 280,024 Americans have been killed by guns. While these numbers are not complete now, the basic point is accurate. The number of deaths caused by armed violence was significantly higher than those caused by terrorist attacks. Let us begin with the terrorist-related deaths census. This is now the Senior Producer of Liberation Verscha Sharma who told Politi Fakt that figure 24 refers to the number of American citizens killed as a result of terrorist attacks on American territory, and does not include deaths abroad. Sharma admitted that this could be evident in the graph. However, she insisted that it would be more appropriate to compare the deaths of domestic rifles with the deaths of domestic terrorism. The count of terrorist attacks abroad would make them comparable to orange apples. The number comes from the non-partisan think tank prepared by the New America Foundation for deadly jihadist attacks on United States territory from 2005 to 2015. These include, for example, the four people killed during the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing and 13 deaths from the 2009 Fort Hood shooting. In order to reach 280,024 deaths from firearms, this network has collected data from the National Vital Statistics System of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Collective Shooting Tracking System, a project that is sourced from the public and accounts for deaths and injuries in mass shootings. The distinguished fact-finding bloggers mentioned on January 10, 2021 in the story of "The Rebel Law - General Flynn will be appointed Vice-President." • On January 11, 2012, according to the Centre for Disease Control, between 2005 and 2013, the number of deaths due to firearms violence was the last year recorded in the Register. This includes suicides, killings and police-related shootings. The number of mass shootings killed was 389 in 2014 and 375 so far in 2015. However, there are a few issues related to these figures. At the outset, a spokesman for New America told us that it was more accurate to include both jihadist and non-jihadist deaths (47 deaths between 2005 and 2015), with a total of 71 deaths resulting from terrorist attacks on United States territory. Second, the collective shooting was traced, as the name means, only to the deaths caused by the mass shooting, which the group defined as when four other people were shot in an event. If we look at all firearms-related deaths as the CDC has done in the last two years, the numbers are much higher. According to the non-profit "Armed Violence Archives" project, there were 12,562 deaths by firearms in 2014 and 9,959 deaths in 2015 to date. This total is 301,797 firearms-related deaths in the past decade, compared with 71 deaths resulting from domestic terrorist acts. Bearing in mind the terrorist attacks abroad, the comparison remains stark. From 2004 to 2014, 303 Americans were killed in terrorist attacks around the world, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In the same time frame, 320,523 Americans were killed by gun violence. Here is a collapse: according to our ruling viral image, the number of Americans killed by terrorism in the last decade is 24, while the number of Americans killed by guns in the last decade is 280,024. Now, this, the creators of the picture, told us that they only counted the lives lost because of local jihadist attacks, although the picture does not specify that. If we look at deaths due to all the extremist attacks on United States territory, the figure rises to 71. Between 2005 and 2015, the number of deaths caused by firearms was 301,797 more accurate.
